pullRequest.body:
This PR shows that a function `f : ℝ → ℝ` is not differentiable at a point if its derivative tends to infinity at that point.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:

- ...

Deletions:

- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ nhdsWithin_Iio_basis`

</details>
Ruben now has status "busy". Any chance we can request someone else to review? I'm afraid I'll start losing track of all the PRs that are blocked by other PRs...

In case there's anything I missed that you think still needs doing here: 

bors d+

:v: dupuisf can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10286678676/job/28467928814)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10286678676/job/28467930115)
Thanks!
Thanks!

```suggestion
  · intro hcontra
    have := hcontra.continuousWithinAt
    rw [← ContinuousWithinAt.diff_iff this] at hcont_at_a
    simp at hcont_at_a
```

Alternatively,
```
  by_cases hcont_at_a : ContinuousWithinAt f (Ici a) a
  case neg =>
    sorry
  case pos =>
    sorry
```

```suggestion
    have h₀ : ∀ᶠ b in 𝓝[>] a,
```
also below

```suggestion
    have h₁ : ∀ᶠ b in 𝓝[>] a, slope f a b < derivWithin f (Ioi a) a + 1 := by
```

```suggestion
        have : derivWithin f (Ioi a) z ≠ 0 := ne_of_gt <| by
```

```suggestion
    rw [Pi.neg_def, deriv.neg']
    exact tendsto_neg_atBot_atTop.comp hf
```

```suggestion
    · intro x
      simp [neg_lt]
```

```suggestion
    rw [Pi.neg_def, deriv.neg']
    exact tendsto_neg_atTop_atBot.comp hf
```
Does this do anything now?
Indeed it doesn't.
I wonder if these three lines can be `rw [← Set.diff_singleton_eq_self not_mem_Ioi_self]`
Does this generalize to `nhdsWithin a s` somehow?
I'm not too sure how to do it in that case -- this uses the mean value theorem, which won't work if there are "holes" in `s`.
@eric-wieser I don't understand what lemma statement you could have in mind...

The statement I had in mind is
```suggestion
    (hf : Tendsto (deriv f) (nhdsWithin a s) atTop) : ¬ DifferentiableWithinAt ℝ f s a := by
```
perhaps also with `IsOpen s`; though I don't make any particularly strong claim that this is reasonable. My comment was for another more-qualified reviewer to remark the sensibility of, not a direct request for a change.
Not sensible. This requires MVT.

Currently, topology/derivatives mostly use [ContinuousWithinAt.mono_of_mem](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/ContinuousOn.html#ContinuousWithinAt.mono_of_mem) spelling.
I changed the proof to use `ContinuousWithinAt.mono_of_mem` instead, and deleted this new lemma.

An alternative proof using Darboux theorem (e.g., [Set.OrdConnected.image_derivWithin](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/Calculus/Darboux.html#Set.OrdConnected.image_derivWithin)): if `f'` tends to infinity, then `f` is differentiable on `[a, b]` for some `b > a` but `f' x > c > f' a` for all `a < x < b`, which is impossible because of Darboux thm. Also, this proof works the same way for left and right nhds.

I had a quick look, but it doesn't seem significantly less painful than this proof, at least not enough to be worth a complete rewrite. Most of the pain in this version involves proving continuity on `Icc a b`, and that's easier than proving differentiability on the same interval.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(Calculus/MeanValue): A function is not differentiable if its derivative tends to infinity
